title: Sukarno
text:
Sukarno (; born Koesno Sosrodihardjo, ; 6 June 1901 – 21 June 1970) was an <a href="Indonesian%20people">Indonesian</a> <a href="wikt%3Astatesman">statesman</a>, <a href="orator">orator</a>, revolutionary, and nationalist who was the first <a href="president%20of%20Indonesia">president of Indonesia</a>, serving from 1945 to 1967.
Sukarno was the leader of the Indonesian struggle for independence from the <a href="Dutch%20East%20Indies">Dutch colonialists</a>. He was a prominent leader of <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Party">Indonesia's nationalist movement</a> during the <a href="Dutch%20East%20Indies">colonial period</a> and spent over a decade under Dutch detention until released by the <a href="Dutch%20East%20Indies%20campaign">invading</a> <a href="Empire%20of%20Japan">Japanese</a> forces in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. Sukarno and his fellow nationalists <a href="Collaboration%20with%20the%20Axis%20Powers%23Indonesia">collaborated</a> to garner support for the Japanese war effort from the population, in exchange for Japanese aid in spreading nationalist ideas. Upon <a href="Surrender%20of%20Japan">Japanese surrender</a>, Sukarno and <a href="Mohammad%20Hatta">Mohammad Hatta</a> <a href="Proclamation%20of%20Indonesian%20Independence">declared Indonesian independence</a> on 17 August 1945, and Sukarno was appointed as its president. He led Indonesians in <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Revolution">resisting Dutch re-colonisation efforts</a> via diplomatic and military means until the <a href="Dutch%E2%80%93Indonesian%20Round%20Table%20Conference">Dutch recognition of Indonesian independence</a> in 1949. Author <a href="Pramoedya%20Ananta%20Toer">Pramoedya Ananta Toer</a> once wrote, "Sukarno was the only Asian leader of the modern era able to unify people of such differing ethnic, cultural and religious backgrounds without shedding a drop of blood."
After a chaotic period of <a href="parliamentary%20democracy">parliamentary democracy</a>, Sukarno established an autocratic system called "<a href="Guided%20Democracy%20in%20Indonesia">Guided Democracy</a>" in 1959 that successfully ended the instability and rebellions which were threatening the survival of the diverse and fractious country. The early 1960s saw Sukarno veering Indonesia to <a href="Left-wing%20politics">the left</a> by providing support and protection to the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Indonesia">Communist Party of Indonesia</a> (PKI) to the irritation of the <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Armed%20Forces">military</a> and <a href="Islamism">Islamists</a>. He also embarked on a series of aggressive foreign policies under the rubric of <a href="anti-imperialism">anti-imperialism</a>, with aid from the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="China">China</a>. After the events surrounding the <a href="30%20September%20Movement">30 September Movement</a>, the military general <a href="Suharto">Suharto</a> largely took control of the country and destroyed the PKI with <a href="Indonesian%20mass%20killings%20of%201965%E2%80%9366">executions of its members and sympathisers in several massacres</a>, with support from the CIA and British intelligence services, resulting in an estimated 500,000 to over 1,000,000 deaths. In 1967, <a href="Transition%20to%20the%20New%20Order">Suharto assumed the presidency</a>, replacing Sukarno, who remained under house arrest until his death in 1970.
Name.
The spelling Soekarno, based on <a href="Dutch%20alphabet%23Sound%20to%20spelling%20correspondences">Dutch orthography</a>, is still in frequent use, mainly because he signed his name in the old spelling. Sukarno himself insisted on a "u" in writing, not "oe", but said that he had been told in school to use the Dutch style, and that after 50 years, it was too difficult to change his signature, so still spelled his signature with "oe". Official Indonesian presidential decrees from the period 1947–1968, however, printed his name using the 1947 spelling. The <a href="Soekarno%E2%80%93Hatta%20International%20Airport">Soekarno–Hatta International Airport</a>, which serves the area near Indonesia's capital, <a href="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>, still uses the Dutch spelling.
Indonesians also remember him as Bung" Karno (Brother/Comrade Karno) or Pak" Karno ("Mr. Karno"). Like many <a href="Javanese%20people">Javanese people</a>, he had <a href="Javanese%20name">only one name</a>.
The name was derived from the character in the <a href="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a> Hindu epic, <a href="Karna">Karna</a>. He is sometimes referred to in foreign accounts as "Achmad Sukarno", or some variation thereof. The fictitious first name may have been added by Western journalists confused over someone with just a single name, or by Indonesian supporters of independence to attract support from Muslim countries. Source from Ministry of Foreign Affairs later revealed, "Achmad" (later, written as "Ahmad" or "Ahmed" by Arabian states and other foreign state press) was coined by M. Zein Hassan, an Indonesian student at <a href="Al-Azhar%20University">Al-Azhar University</a> and later a member of the staff at the Department of Foreign Affairs, to establish Soekarno's identity as a Muslim to the Egyptian press after a brief controversy at that time in Egypt alleging Sukarno's name was "not Muslim enough". After adopting the name "Achmad," Muslim and Arab states freely supported Sukarno. Thus, in correspondence with the Middle East, Sukarno always signed his name as "Achmad Soekarno."
Early life.
Early life and education.
Early life.
The son of a Javanese primary school teacher, an <a href="Aristocracy%20%28class%29">aristocrat</a> named , and his Hindu Balinese wife from the <a href="Brahmin">Brahmin varna</a> named from <a href="Buleleng%20Regency">Buleleng</a>, Sukarno was born in <a href="Surabaya">Surabaya</a> in the <a href="Dutch%20East%20Indies">Dutch East Indies</a> (now Indonesia), where his father had been sent following an application for a transfer to Java. He was originally named Kusno Sosrodihardjo. Following <a href="Javanese%20people">Javanese</a> custom, he was renamed after surviving a childhood illness.
Education.
After graduating from a native primary school in 1912, he was sent to the "Europeesche Lagere School" (a Dutch primary school) in <a href="Mojokerto">Mojokerto</a>. Subsequently, in 1916, Sukarno went to a "<a href="Hogere%20Burgerschool">Hogere Burgerschool</a>" (a Dutch type higher level secondary school) in <a href="Surabaya">Surabaya</a>, where he met <a href="Tjokroaminoto">Tjokroaminoto</a>, a nationalist and founder of <a href="Sarekat%20Islam">Sarekat Islam</a>. In 1920, Sukarno married <a href="Tjokroaminoto">Tjokroaminoto</a>'s daughter Siti Oetari. In 1921, he began to study <a href="civil%20engineering">civil engineering</a> (with a focus on <a href="architecture">architecture</a>) at the "<a href="Technische%20Hoogeschool%20te%20Bandoeng">Technische Hoogeschool te Bandoeng</a>" (Bandoeng Institute of Technology), where he obtained an <a href="Ingenieur">Ingenieur</a> degree (abbreviated as "ir.", a Dutch type <a href="engineer%27s%20degree">engineer's degree</a>) in 1926. During his study in <a href="Bandung">Bandung</a>, Sukarno became romantically involved with Inggit Garnasih, the wife of Sanoesi, the owner of the boarding house where he lived as a student. Inggit was 13 years older than Sukarno. In March 1923, Sukarno divorced Siti Oetari to marry Inggit (who also divorced her husband Sanoesi). Sukarno later divorced Inggit and married Fatmawati.
Atypically even among the country's small educated elite, Sukarno was fluent in several languages. In addition to the <a href="Javanese%20language">Javanese language</a> of his childhood, he was a master of <a href="Sundanese%20language">Sundanese</a>, <a href="Balinese%20language">Balinese</a> and <a href="Indonesian%20language">Indonesian</a>, and was especially strong in Dutch. He was also quite comfortable in <a href="German%20language">German</a>, English, <a href="French%20language">French</a>, <a href="Arabic%20language">Arabic</a>, and <a href="Japanese%20language">Japanese</a>, all of which were taught at his HBS. He was helped by his <a href="photographic%20memory">photographic memory</a> and <a href="child%20prodigy">precocious mind</a>.
In his studies, Sukarno was "intensely modern", both in architecture and in politics. He despised both the traditional Javanese <a href="feudalism">feudalism</a>, which he considered "backward" and to blame for the fall of the country under Dutch occupation and exploitation, and the <a href="imperialism">imperialism</a> practised by <a href="Western%20world">Western</a> countries, which he termed as "exploitation of humans by other humans" ("exploitation de l'homme par l'homme"). He blamed this for the deep poverty and low levels of education of Indonesian people under the Dutch. To promote nationalistic pride amongst Indonesians, Sukarno interpreted these ideas in his dress, in his urban planning for the capital (eventually <a href="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>), and in his <a href="Socialism">socialist</a> politics, though he did not extend his taste for modern art to <a href="pop%20music">pop music</a>; he had <a href="Koes%20Bersaudara">Koes Bersaudara</a> imprisoned for their allegedly decadent lyrics despite his reputation for womanising. For Sukarno, modernity was blind to race, neat and elegant in style, and anti-imperialist.
Architectural career.
Sukarno & Anwari firm.
After graduation in 1926, Sukarno and his university friend Anwari established the architectural firm Sukarno & Anwari in <a href="Bandung">Bandung</a>, which provided planning and contractor services. Among Sukarno's architectural works are the renovated building of the Preanger Hotel (1929), where he acted as assistant to famous Dutch architect <a href="Wolff%20Schoemaker">Charles Prosper Wolff Schoemaker</a>. Sukarno also designed many private houses on today's Jalan Gatot Subroto, Jalan Palasari, and Jalan Dewi Sartika in <a href="Bandung">Bandung</a>. Later on, as president, Sukarno remained engaged in architecture, designing the Proclamation Monument and adjacent "Gedung Pola" in <a href="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>; the Youth Monument ("Tugu Muda") in <a href="Semarang">Semarang</a>; the Alun-alun Monument in <a href="Malang">Malang</a>; the Heroes' Monument in <a href="Surabaya">Surabaya</a>; and also the new city of <a href="Palangkaraya">Palangkaraya</a> in <a href="Central%20Kalimantan">Central Kalimantan</a>.
Early independence struggle.
Sukarno was first exposed to nationalist ideas while living under <a href="Oemar%20Said%20Tjokroaminoto">Oemar Said Tjokroaminoto</a>. Later, while a student in <a href="Bandung">Bandung</a>, he immersed himself in European, American, Nationalist, communist, and religious political philosophy, eventually developing his own political ideology of Indonesian-style socialist self-sufficiency. He began styling his ideas as <a href="Marhaenism">Marhaenism</a>, named after Marhaen, an Indonesian peasant he met in southern Bandung area, who owned his little plot of land and worked on it himself, producing sufficient income to support his family. In university, Sukarno began organising a study club for Indonesian students, the "Algemeene Studieclub", in opposition to the established student clubs dominated by Dutch students.
Involvement in the Indonesian National Party.
On 4 July 1927, Sukarno with his friends from the "Algemeene Studieclub" established a pro-independence party, the <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Party">Indonesian National Party</a> (PNI), of which Sukarno was elected the first leader. The party advocated independence for Indonesia, and opposed imperialism and capitalism because it opined that both systems worsened the life of Indonesian people. The party also advocated <a href="secularism">secularism</a> and unity amongst the many different ethnicities in the <a href="Dutch%20East%20Indies">Dutch East Indies</a>, to establish a united Indonesia. Sukarno also hoped that Japan would commence a war against the western powers and that Java could then gain its independence with Japan's aid. Coming soon after the disintegration of <a href="Sarekat%20Islam">Sarekat Islam</a> in the early 1920s and the crushing of the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Indonesia">Indonesian Communist Party</a> after its failed rebellion of 1926, the PNI began to attract a large number of followers, particularly among the new university-educated youths eager for broader freedoms and opportunities denied to them in the racist and constrictive political system of Dutch colonialism.
Arrest, trial, and imprisonment.
Arrest and trial.
PNI activities came to the attention of the colonial government, and Sukarno's speeches and meetings were often infiltrated and disrupted by agents of the colonial secret police ("Politieke Inlichtingen Dienst"/PID). Eventually, Sukarno and other key PNI leaders were arrested on 29 December 1929 by Dutch colonial authorities in a series of raids throughout Java. Sukarno himself was arrested while on a visit to <a href="Yogyakarta">Yogyakarta</a>. During his trial at the Bandung "Landraad" courthouse from August to December 1930, Sukarno made a series of long political speeches attacking colonialism and imperialism, titled "Indonesia Menggoegat" ("<a href="Indonesia%20Accuses">Indonesia Accuses</a>").
Sentence and imprisonment.
In December 1930, Sukarno was sentenced to four years in prison, which were served in Sukamiskin prison in Bandung. His speech, however, received extensive coverage by the press, and due to strong pressure from the liberal elements in both Netherlands and <a href="Dutch%20East%20Indies">Dutch East Indies</a>, Sukarno was released early on 31 December 1931. By this time, he had become a popular hero widely known throughout Indonesia.
However, during his imprisonment, the PNI had been splintered by the oppression of colonial authorities and internal dissension. The original PNI was disbanded by the Dutch, and its former members formed two different parties; the <a href="Partindo">Indonesia Party (Partindo)</a> under Sukarno's associate <a href="Sartono">Sartono</a> who were promoting mass agitation, and the Indonesian Nationalist Education (New PNI) under <a href="Mohammad%20Hatta">Mohammad Hatta</a> and <a href="Soetan%20Sjahrir">Soetan Sjahrir</a>, two nationalists who recently returned from studies in the Netherlands, and who were promoting a long-term strategy of providing modern education to the uneducated Indonesian populace to develop an intellectual elite able to offer effective resistance to Dutch rule. After attempting to reconcile the two parties to establish one united nationalist front, Sukarno chose to become the head of Partindo on 28 July 1932. Partindo had maintained its alignment with Sukarno's own strategy of immediate mass agitation, and Sukarno disagreed with Hatta's long-term cadre-based struggle. Hatta himself believed Indonesian independence would not occur within his lifetime, while Sukarno believed Hatta's strategy ignored the fact that politics can only make real changes through formation and utilisation of force ("machtsvorming en machtsaanwending").
During this period, to support himself and the party financially, Sukarno returned to architecture, opening the bureau of Soekarno & Roosseno with his university junior <a href="Roosseno">Roosseno</a>. He also wrote articles for the party's newspaper, "Fikiran Ra'jat". While based in Bandung, Sukarno travelled extensively throughout Java to establish contacts with other nationalists. His activities attracted further attention by the Dutch PID. In mid-1933, Sukarno published a series of writings titled "Mentjapai Indonesia Merdeka" ("To Attain Independent Indonesia"). For this writing, he was arrested by Dutch police while visiting fellow nationalist <a href="Mohammad%20Hoesni%20Thamrin">Mohammad Hoesni Thamrin</a> in Jakarta on 1 August 1933.
Exile.
This time, to prevent providing Sukarno with a platform to make political speeches, the hardline governor-general <a href="Jonkheer">Jonkheer</a> <a href="Bonifacius%20Cornelis%20de%20Jonge">Bonifacius Cornelis de Jonge</a> utilised his emergency powers to send Sukarno to internal exile without trial. In 1934, Sukarno was shipped, along with his family (including Inggit Garnasih), to the remote town of <a href="Ende%2C%20Indonesia">Ende</a>, on the island of <a href="Flores">Flores</a>. During his time in Flores, he utilised his limited freedom of movement to establish a children's theatre. Among its members was future politician <a href="Frans%20Seda">Frans Seda</a>. Due to an outbreak of malaria in Flores, the Dutch authorities decided to move Sukarno and his family to <a href="Bengkulu">Bencoolen</a> (now Bengkulu) on the western coast of <a href="Sumatra">Sumatra</a>, in February 1938.
In <a href="Bengkulu">Bengkulu</a>, Sukarno became acquainted with Hassan Din, the local head of <a href="Muhammadiyah">Muhammadiyah</a> organisation, and he was allowed to teach religious teachings at a local school owned by the <a href="Muhammadiyah">Muhammadiyah</a>. One of his students was 15-year-old <a href="Fatmawati">Fatmawati</a>, daughter of Hassan Din. He became romantically involved with Fatmawati, which he justified by stating the inability of Inggit Garnasih to produce children during their almost 20-year marriage. Sukarno was still in Bengkulu exile when the Japanese <a href="Dutch%20East%20Indies%20campaign">invaded</a> the archipelago in 1942.
World War II and the Japanese occupation.
Japanese occupation.
Background and Invasion.
In early 1929, during the <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Revival">Indonesian National Revival</a>, Sukarno and fellow Indonesian nationalist leader <a href="Mohammad%20Hatta">Mohammad Hatta</a> (later <a href="List%20of%20Vice%20Presidents%20of%20Indonesia">Vice President</a>), first foresaw a Pacific War and the opportunity that a Japanese advance on Indonesia might present for the Indonesian independence cause. In February 1942 <a href="Imperial%20Japan">Imperial Japan</a> invaded the <a href="Dutch%20East%20Indies">Dutch East Indies</a> quickly defeating Dutch forces who marched, bussed and trucked Sukarno and his entourage three hundred kilometres from <a href="Bengkulu">Bengkulu</a> to <a href="Padang%2C%20Indonesia">Padang</a>, <a href="Sumatra">Sumatra</a>. They intended keeping him prisoner and shipping him to Australia but abruptly abandoned him to save themselves upon the impending approach of Japanese forces on Padang.
Cooperation with the Japanese.
The Japanese had their own files on Sukarno, and the Japanese commander in <a href="Sumatra">Sumatra</a> approached him with respect, wanting to use him to organise and pacify the Indonesians. Sukarno, on the other hand, wanted to use the Japanese to gain independence for Indonesia: "The Lord be praised, God showed me the way; in that valley of the Ngarai I said: Yes, Independent Indonesia can only be achieved with Dai Nippon...For the first time in all my life, I saw myself in the mirror of Asia." In July 1942, Sukarno was sent back to <a href="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>, where he re-united with other nationalist leaders recently released by the Japanese, including <a href="Mohammad%20Hatta">Mohammad Hatta</a>. There, he met the Japanese commander General <a href="Hitoshi%20Imamura">Hitoshi Imamura</a>, who asked Sukarno and other nationalists to galvanise support from Indonesian populace to aid the Japanese war effort.
Sukarno was willing to support the Japanese, in exchange for a platform for himself to spread nationalist ideas to the mass population. The Japanese, on the other hand, needed Indonesia's workforce and natural resources to help its war effort. The Japanese recruited millions of people, mainly from <a href="Java">Java</a>, to be forced labour called "<a href="romusha">romusha</a>" in <a href="Japanese%20language">Japanese</a>. They were forced to build railways, airfields, and other facilities for the Japanese within Indonesia and as far away as Burma. Additionally, the Japanese requisitioned rice and other food produced by Indonesian peasants to supply their troops, while forcing the peasantry to cultivate <a href="castor%20oil">castor oil</a> plants to be used as aviation fuel and lubricants.
To gain cooperation from Indonesian population and to prevent resistance to these measures, the Japanese put Sukarno as head of "Tiga-A" mass organisation movement. In March 1943, the Japanese formed a new organisation called "Poesat Tenaga Rakjat" (POETERA/ Center of People's Power) under Sukarno, Hatta, <a href="Ki%20Hadjar%20Dewantara">Ki Hadjar Dewantara</a>, and <a href="Mas%20Mansur">KH Mas Mansjoer</a>. These organisations aimed to galvanise popular support for recruitment of "romusha", to requisition of food products, and to promote pro-Japanese and <a href="anti-Western%20sentiment">anti-Western sentiment</a>s amongst Indonesians. Sukarno coined the term, "Amerika kita setrika, Inggris kita linggis" ("Let's iron America, and bludgeon the British") to promote anti-Allied sentiments. In later years, Sukarno was lastingly ashamed of his role with the "romusha". Additionally, food requisitioning by the Japanese caused widespread famine in Java, which killed more than one million people in 1944–1945. In his view, these were necessary sacrifices to be made to allow for the future independence of Indonesia. He also was involved with the formation of "<a href="PETA%20%28Indonesia%29">Pembela Tanah Air</a>" (PETA) and Heiho (Indonesian volunteer army troops) via speeches broadcast on the Japanese radio and loudspeaker networks across Java and Sumatra. By mid-1945 these units numbered around two million and were preparing to defeat any Allied forces sent to re-take Java.
In the meantime, Sukarno eventually divorced Inggit, who refused to accept her husband's wish for polygamy. She was provided with a house in <a href="Bandung">Bandung</a> and a pension for the rest of her life. In 1943, he married <a href="Fatmawati">Fatmawati</a>. They lived in a house in Jalan Pegangsaan Timur No. 56, confiscated from its previous Dutch owners and presented to Sukarno by the Japanese. This house would later be the venue of the <a href="Proclamation%20of%20Indonesian%20Independence">Proclamation of Indonesian Independence</a> in 1945.
On 10 November 1943 Sukarno and Hatta were sent on a 17-day tour of Japan, where they were decorated by Emperor <a href="Hirohito">Hirohito</a> and wined and dined in the house of Prime Minister <a href="Hideki%20Tojo">Hideki Tojo</a> in <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>. On 7 September 1944, with the war going badly for the Japanese, <a href="Kuniaki%20Koiso">Prime Minister Kuniaki Koiso</a> promised independence for Indonesia, although no date was set. This announcement was seen, according to the U.S. official history, as immense vindication for Sukarno's apparent collaboration with the Japanese. The U.S. at the time considered Sukarno one of the "foremost collaborationist leaders."
Investigating Committee for Preparatory Work for Independence.
On 29 April 1945, with the fall of <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a> to American hands, the Japanese allowed for the establishment of the <a href="Investigating%20Committee%20for%20Preparatory%20Work%20for%20Independence">Investigating Committee for Preparatory Work for Independence</a> (BPUPK), a quasi-legislature consisting of 67 representatives from most ethnic groups in Indonesia. Sukarno was appointed as head of the BPUPK and was tasked to lead discussions to prepare the basis of a future Indonesian state. To provide a common and acceptable platform to unite the various squabbling factions in the BPUPK, Sukarno formulated his ideological thinking developed for the past twenty years into five principles. On 1 June 1945, he introduced these five principles, known as "<a href="Pancasila%20%28politics%29">pancasila</a>", during the joint session of the BPUPK held in the former <a href="Volksraad%20%28Dutch%20East%20Indies%29">Volksraad</a> Building (now called "Gedung Pancasila").
"Pancasila", as presented by Sukarno during the BPUPK speech, consisted of five principles which Sukarno saw as commonly shared by all Indonesians:
On 22 June, the Islamic and nationalist elements of the BPUPK created a small committee of nine, which formulated Sukarno's ideas into the five-point <a href="Pancasila%20%28politics%29">Pancasila</a>, in a document known as the <a href="Jakarta%20Charter">Jakarta Charter</a>:
Due to pressure from the Islamic element, the first principle mentioned the obligation for Muslims to practice Islamic law (<a href="sharia">sharia</a>). However, the final Sila as contained in the 1945 Constitution which was put into effect on 18 August 1945, excluded the reference to Islamic law for the sake of national unity. The elimination of <a href="sharia">sharia</a> was done by <a href="Mohammad%20Hatta">Mohammad Hatta</a> based upon a request by Christian representative <a href="Alexander%20Andries%20Maramis">Alexander Andries Maramis</a>, and after consultation with moderate Islamic representatives Teuku Mohammad Hassan, Kasman Singodimedjo, and Ki Bagoes Hadikoesoemo.
Preparatory Committee for Indonesian Independence.
On 7 August 1945, the Japanese allowed the formation of a smaller <a href="Preparatory%20Committee%20for%20Indonesian%20Independence">Preparatory Committee for Indonesian Independence</a> (PPKI), a 21-person committee tasked with creating the specific governmental structure of the future Indonesian state. On 9 August, the top leaders of PPKI (Sukarno, Hatta, and <a href="Radjiman%20Wediodiningrat">KRT Radjiman Wediodiningrat</a>), were summoned by Commander-in-Chief of Japan's Southern Expeditionary Forces, Field Marshal <a href="Hisaichi%20Terauchi">Hisaichi Terauchi</a>, to <a href="Da%20Lat">Da Lat</a>, 100 km from <a href="Saigon">Saigon</a>. Field Marshal Terauchi gave Sukarno the freedom to proceed with preparation for Indonesian independence, free of Japanese interference. After much wining and dining, Sukarno's entourage was flown back to Jakarta on 14 August. Unbeknownst to the guests, <a href="Atomic%20bombings%20of%20Hiroshima%20and%20Nagasaki">atomic bombs had been dropped</a> on <a href="Hiroshima">Hiroshima</a> and <a href="Nagasaki">Nagasaki</a>, and the Japanese were preparing for <a href="Surrender%20of%20Japan">surrender</a>.
Japanese surrender.
The following day, on 15 August, the Japanese declared their acceptance of the <a href="Potsdam%20Declaration">Potsdam Declaration</a> terms and unconditionally surrendered to the Allies. On the afternoon of that day, Sukarno received this information from leaders of youth groups and members of PETA <a href="Chairul%20Saleh">Chairul Saleh</a>, <a href="Soekarni">Soekarni</a>, and <a href="Wikana">Wikana</a>, who had been listening to Western radio broadcasts. They urged Sukarno to declare Indonesian independence immediately, while the Japanese were in confusion and before the arrival of Allied forces. Faced with this quick turn of events, Sukarno procrastinated. He feared bloodbath due to hostile response from the Japanese to such a move and was concerned with prospects of future Allied retribution.
Kidnapping.
At early morning on 16 August, the three youth leaders, impatient with Sukarno's indecision, kidnapped him from his house and brought him to a small house in Rengasdengklok, <a href="Karawang">Karawang</a>, owned by a Chinese family and occupied by PETA. There they gained Sukarno's commitment to declare independence the next day. That night, the youths drove Sukarno back to the house of Admiral Tadashi Maeda, the Japanese naval liaison officer in the <a href="Menteng">Menteng</a> area of Jakarta, who sympathised with Indonesian independence. There, he and his assistant Sajoeti Melik prepared the text of the <a href="Proclamation%20of%20Indonesian%20Independence">Proclamation of Indonesian Independence</a>.
Indonesian National Revolution.
Proclamation of Indonesian Independence.
In the early morning of 17 August 1945, Sukarno returned to his house at Jalan Pegangsaan Timur No. 56, where <a href="Mohammad%20Hatta">Mohammad Hatta</a> joined him. Throughout the morning, impromptu leaflets printed by <a href="Pembela%20Tanah%20Air">PETA</a> and youth elements informed the population of the impending proclamation. Finally, at 10 am, Sukarno and Hatta stepped to the front porch, where Sukarno declared the <a href="Indonesian%20Declaration%20of%20Independence">independence of the Republic of Indonesia</a> in front of a crowd of 500 people. This most historic of buildings had, however, been ordered to be demolished by Sukarno himself, without any apparent reason.
On the following day, 18 August, the PPKI declared the basic governmental structure of the new Republic of Indonesia:
Sukarno's vision for the 1945 Indonesian <a href="Constitution%20of%20Indonesia">constitution</a> comprised the <a href="Pancasila%20Indonesia">Pancasila</a> ("five principles"). Sukarno's political philosophy was mainly a fusion of elements of <a href="Marxism">Marxism</a>, <a href="nationalism">nationalism</a> and <a href="Islam">Islam</a>. This is reflected in a proposition of his version of Pancasila he proposed to the <a href="Investigating%20Committee%20for%20Preparatory%20Work%20for%20Independence">Investigating Committee for Preparatory Work for Independence</a> (BPUPK) in a speech on 1 June 1945.
Sukarno argued that all of the principles of the nation could be summarised in the phrase "<a href="gotong%20royong">gotong royong</a>." The Indonesian parliament, founded on the basis of this original (and subsequently revised) constitution, proved all but ungovernable. This was due to irreconcilable differences between various social, political, religious and ethnic factions.
Revolution and Bersiap.
In the days following the proclamation, the news of Indonesian independence was spread by radio, newspaper, leaflets, and word of mouth despite attempts by the Japanese soldiers to suppress the news. On 19 September, Sukarno addressed a crowd of one million people at the Ikada Field of Jakarta (now part of <a href="Merdeka%20Square%2C%20Jakarta">Merdeka Square</a>) to commemorate one month of independence, indicating the strong level of popular support for the new Republic, at least on Java and Sumatra. In these two islands, the Sukarno government quickly established governmental control while the remaining Japanese mostly retreated to their barracks awaiting the arrival of Allied forces. This period was marked by constant attacks by armed groups on Europeans, Chinese, Christians, native aristocracy and anyone who were perceived to oppose Indonesian independence. The most serious cases were the Social Revolutions in <a href="Aceh">Aceh</a> and <a href="North%20Sumatra">North Sumatra</a>, where large numbers of Acehnese and Malay aristocrats were killed by Islamic groups (in Aceh) and communist-led mobs (in North Sumatra), and the "Three Regions Affair" in northwestern coast of <a href="Central%20Java">Central Java</a> where large numbers of Europeans, Chinese, and native aristocrats were butchered by mobs. These bloody incidences continued until late 1945 to early 1946, and begin to peter-out as Republican authorities begin to exert and consolidate control.
Sukarno's government initially postponed the formation of a national army, for fear of antagonizing the Allied occupation forces and their doubt over whether they would have been able to form an adequate military apparatus to maintain control of seized territory. The members of various <a href="militia">militia</a> groups formed during Japanese occupation such as the disbanded PETA and Heiho, at that time were encouraged to join the BKR—"Badan Keamanan Rakjat" (The People's Security Organization)—itself a subordinate of the "War Victims Assistance Organization". It was only in October 1945 that the BKR was reformed into the TKR—"Tentara Keamanan Rakjat" (The People's Security Army) in response to the increasing Allied and Dutch presence in Indonesia. The TKR armed themselves mostly by attacking Japanese troops and confiscating their weapons.
Due to the sudden transfer of Java and Sumatra from General <a href="Douglas%20MacArthur">Douglas MacArthur</a>'s American-controlled Southwest Pacific Command to <a href="Lord%20Louis%20Mountbatten">Lord Louis Mountbatten</a>'s British-controlled Southeast Asian Command, the first Allied soldiers (1st Battalion of Seaforth Highlanders) did not arrive in Jakarta until late September 1945. British forces began to occupy major Indonesian cities in October 1945. The commander of the British 23rd Division, Lieutenant General Sir <a href="Philip%20Christison">Philip Christison</a>, set up command in the former governor-general's palace in Jakarta. Christison stated that he intended to free all Allied prisoners-of-war and to allow the return of Indonesia to its pre-war status, as a colony of Netherlands. The Republican government were willing to cooperate with the release and repatriation of Allied civilians and military POWs, setting-up the Committee for the Repatriation of Japanese and Allied Prisoners of Wars and Internees ("Panitia Oeroesan Pengangkoetan Djepang dan APWI"/POPDA) for this purpose. POPDA, in cooperation with the British, repatriated more than 70,000 Japanese and Allied POWs and internees by the end of 1946. However, due to the relative weakness of the military of the Republic of Indonesia, Sukarno sought independence by gaining international recognition for his new country rather than engage in battle with British and Dutch military forces.
Sukarno was aware that his history as a Japanese <a href="Collaboration">collaborator</a> and his leadership in the Japanese-approved during the occupation would make the Western countries distrustful of him. To help gain international recognition as well as to accommodate domestic demands for representation, Sukarno "allowed" the formation of a parliamentary system of government, whereby a <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Indonesia">prime minister</a> controlled day-to-day affairs of the government, while Sukarno as president remained as a figurehead. The prime minister and his cabinet would be responsible to the <a href="Central%20Indonesian%20National%20Committee">Central Indonesian National Committee</a> instead of the president. On 14 November 1945, Sukarno appointed <a href="Sutan%20Sjahrir">Sutan Sjahrir</a> as first prime minister; he was a European-educated politician who was never involved with the Japanese occupation authorities.
In late 1945 Dutch administrators who led the Dutch East Indies government-in-exile and soldiers who had fought the Japanese began to return under the name of Netherlands Indies Civil Administration (NICA), with the protection of the British. They were led by <a href="Hubertus%20Johannes%20van%20Mook">Hubertus Johannes van Mook</a>, a colonial administrator who had evacuated to <a href="Brisbane">Brisbane</a>, Australia. Dutch soldiers who had been POWs under the Japanese were released and rearmed. Shooting between these Dutch soldiers and police supporting the new Republican government Indonesian and civilians soon developed. This soon escalated to armed conflict between the newly constituted Republican forces aided by a myriad of pro-independence mobs and the Dutch and British forces. On 10 November, a full-scale <a href="Battle%20of%20Surabaya">battle</a> broke out in <a href="Surabaya">Surabaya</a> between the 49th Infantry Brigade of the <a href="British%20Indian%20Army">British Indian Army</a> and Indonesian nationalist militias. The British-Indian force were supported by air and naval forces. Some 300 Indian soldiers were killed (including their commander Brigadier <a href="Aubertin%20Walter%20Sothern%20Mallaby">Aubertin Walter Sothern Mallaby</a>), as were thousands of nationalist militiamen and other Indonesians. Shootouts broke out with alarming regularity in <a href="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>, including an attempted assassination of Prime Minister <a href="Sjahrir">Sjahrir</a> by Dutch gunmen. To avoid this menace, Sukarno and majority of his government left for the safety of <a href="Yogyakarta">Yogyakarta</a> on 4 January 1946. There, the Republican government received protection and full support from Sultan <a href="Hamengkubuwono%20IX">Hamengkubuwono IX</a>. Yogyakarta would remain as the Republic's capital until the end of the war in 1949. <a href="Sjahrir">Sjahrir</a> remained in Jakarta to conduct negotiations with the British.
The initial series of battles in late 1945 and early 1946 left the British in control of major port cities on Java and Sumatra. During the Japanese occupation, the Outer Islands (excluding Java and Sumatra) were occupied by the Japanese Navy (<a href="Kaigun">Kaigun</a>), who did not allow for political mobilisation of the islanders. Consequently, there was little Republican activity in these islands post-proclamation. Australian and Dutch forces were able to quickly take control of these islands without much fighting by the end of 1945 (excluding the resistance of <a href="I%20Gusti%20Ngurah%20Rai">I Gusti Ngurah Rai</a> in Bali, the insurgency in <a href="South%20Sulawesi">South Sulawesi</a>, and fighting in Hulu Sungai area of <a href="South%20Kalimantan">South Kalimantan</a>). Meanwhile, the hinterland areas of Java and Sumatra remained under Republican control.
Eager to pull its soldiers out of Indonesia, the British allowed for large-scale infusion of Dutch forces into the country throughout 1946. By November 1946, all British soldiers had been withdrawn from Indonesia. They were replaced with more than 150,000 Dutch soldiers. The British sent Lord <a href="Archibald%20Clark%20Kerr%2C%201st%20Baron%20Inverchapel">Archibald Clark Kerr, 1st Baron Inverchapel</a> and <a href="Miles%20Lampson%2C%201st%20Baron%20Killearn">Miles Lampson, 1st Baron Killearn</a> to bring the Dutch and Indonesians to the negotiating table. The result of these negotiations was the <a href="Linggadjati%20Agreement">Linggadjati Agreement</a> signed in November 1946, where the Dutch acknowledged "<a href="de%20facto">de facto</a>" Republican sovereignty over Java, Sumatra, and Madura. In exchange, the Republicans were willing to discuss a future Commonwealth-like United Kingdom of Netherlands and Indonesia.
Linggadjati Agreement and Operation Product.
Linggadjati Agreement.
Sukarno's decision to negotiate with the Dutch was met with strong opposition by various Indonesian factions. <a href="Tan%20Malaka">Tan Malaka</a>, a <a href="Indonesian%20Communist%20Party">communist</a> politician, organised these groups into a united front called the "Persatoean Perdjoangan" (PP). PP offered a "Minimum Program" which called for complete independence, nationalisation of all foreign properties, and rejection of all negotiations until all foreign troops are withdrawn. These programmes received widespread popular support, including from armed forces commander General <a href="Sudirman">Sudirman</a>. On 4 July 1946, military units linked with PP kidnapped Prime Minister <a href="Sjahrir">Sjahrir</a> who was visiting <a href="Yogyakarta">Yogyakarta</a>. Sjahrir was leading the negotiation with the Dutch. Sukarno, after successfully influencing <a href="Sudirman">Sudirman</a>, managed to secure the release of Sjahrir and the arrest of <a href="Tan%20Malaka">Tan Malaka</a> and other PP leaders. Disapproval of Linggadjati terms within the <a href="Central%20Indonesian%20National%20Committee">KNIP</a> led Sukarno to issue a decree doubling KNIP membership by including many pro-agreement appointed members. As a consequence, KNIP ratified the <a href="Linggadjati%20Agreement">Linggadjati Agreement</a> in March 1947.
Operation Product.
On 21 July 1947, the <a href="Linggadjati%20Agreement">Linggadjati Agreement</a> was broken by the Dutch, who launched <a href="Operatie%20Product">Operatie Product</a>, a massive military invasion into Republican-held territories. Although the newly reconstituted <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Armed%20Forces">TNI</a> was unable to offer significant military resistance, the blatant violation by the Dutch of an internationally brokered agreement outraged world opinion. International pressure forced the Dutch to halt their invasion force in August 1947. Sjahrir, who has been replaced as prime minister by <a href="Amir%20Sjarifuddin">Amir Sjarifuddin</a>, flew to <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> to appeal Indonesian case in front of <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a>. UN Security Council issued a resolution calling for an immediate ceasefire and appointed a Good Offices Committee (GOC) to oversee the ceasefire. The GOC, based in Jakarta, consisted of delegations from Australia (led by <a href="Richard%20Kirby%20%28arbitrator%29">Richard Kirby</a>, chosen by Indonesia), Belgium (led by <a href="Paul%20van%20Zeeland">Paul van Zeeland</a>, chosen by the Netherlands), and United States (led by <a href="Frank%20Porter%20Graham">Frank Porter Graham</a>, neutral).
The Republic was now under firm Dutch military stranglehold, with the Dutch military occupying <a href="West%20Java">West Java</a>, and the northern coast of <a href="Central%20Java">Central Java</a> and <a href="East%20Java">East Java</a>, along with the key productive areas of <a href="Sumatra">Sumatra</a>. Additionally, the Dutch navy blockaded Republican areas from supplies of vital food, medicine, and weapons. As a consequence, Prime Minister <a href="Amir%20Sjarifuddin">Amir Sjarifuddin</a> had little choice but to sign the <a href="Renville%20Agreement">Renville Agreement</a> on 17 January 1948, which acknowledged Dutch control over areas taken during <a href="Operatie%20Product">Operatie Product</a>, while the Republicans pledged to withdraw all forces that remained on the other side of the ceasefire line ("Van Mook Line"). Meanwhile, the Dutch begin to organise <a href="Puppet%20government">puppet states</a> in the areas under their occupation, to counter Republican influence utilising ethnic diversity of Indonesia.
Renville agreement and Madiun affair.
The signing of highly disadvantageous Renville Agreement caused even greater instability within the Republican political structure. In Dutch-occupied West Java, <a href="Darul%20Islam%20%28Indonesia%29">Darul Islam</a> <a href="guerrilla%20warfare">guerrillas</a> under <a href="Sekarmadji%20Maridjan%20Kartosuwirjo">Sekarmadji Maridjan Kartosuwirjo</a> maintained their anti-Dutch resistance and repealed any loyalty to the Republic; they caused a bloody insurgency in West Java and other areas in the first decades of independence. Prime Minister <a href="Amir%20Sjarifuddin">Sjarifuddin</a>, who signed the agreement, was forced to resign in January 1948 and was replaced by <a href="Mohammad%20Hatta">Mohammad Hatta</a>. Hatta cabinet's policy of rationalising the armed forces by demobilising large numbers of armed groups that proliferated the Republican areas also caused severe disaffection. Leftist political elements, led by resurgent <a href="Indonesian%20Communist%20Party">Indonesian Communist Party (PKI)</a> under <a href="Musso">Musso</a> took advantage of public disaffections by launching a rebellion in <a href="Madiun">Madiun</a>, <a href="East%20Java">East Java</a>, on 18 September 1948. Bloody fighting continued during late-September until end of October 1948, when the last communist bands were defeated, and Musso shot dead. The communists had overestimated their potential to oppose the strong appeal of Sukarno amongst the population.
Operatie Kraai and exile.
Invasion and exile.
On 19 December 1948, to take advantage of the Republic's weak position following the communist rebellion, the Dutch launched <a href="Operatie%20Kraai">Operatie Kraai</a>, a second military invasion designed to crush the Republic once and for all. The invasion was initiated with an airborne assault on Republican capital <a href="Yogyakarta">Yogyakarta</a>. Sukarno ordered the armed forces under <a href="Sudirman">Sudirman</a> to launch a guerrilla campaign in the countryside, while he and other key leaders such as Hatta and <a href="Sjahrir">Sjahrir</a> allowed themselves to be taken prisoner by the Dutch. To ensure continuity of government, Sukarno sent a telegram to <a href="Sjafruddin%20Prawiranegara">Sjafruddin Prawiranegara</a>, providing him with the mandate to lead an Emergency Government of the Republic of Indonesia (PDRI), based on the unoccupied hinterlands of <a href="West%20Sumatra">West Sumatra</a>, a position he kept until Sukarno was released in June 1949. The Dutch sent Sukarno and other captured Republican leaders to captivity in Prapat, in Dutch-occupied part of <a href="North%20Sumatra">North Sumatra</a> and later to the island of <a href="Bangka%20Island">Bangka</a>.
Aftermath.
The second Dutch invasion caused even more international outrage. The United States, impressed by Indonesia's ability to defeat the 1948 communist challenge without outside help, threatened to cut off <a href="Marshall%20Aid">Marshall Aid</a> funds to the Netherlands if military operations in Indonesia continued. TNI did not disintegrate and continued to wage guerrilla resistance against the Dutch, most notably the assault on Dutch-held Yogyakarta led by <a href="Lieutenant-Colonel">Lieutenant-Colonel</a> <a href="Suharto">Suharto</a> on 1 March 1949. Consequently, the Dutch were forced to sign the <a href="Roem%E2%80%93Van%20Roijen%20Agreement">Roem–Van Roijen Agreement</a> on 7 May 1949. According to this treaty, the Dutch released the Republican leadership and returned the area surrounding <a href="Yogyakarta">Yogyakarta</a> to Republican control in June 1949. This was followed by the <a href="Dutch-Indonesian%20Round%20Table%20Conference">Dutch-Indonesian Round Table Conference</a> held in <a href="The%20Hague">The Hague</a> which led to the complete transfer of <a href="sovereignty">sovereignty</a> by the Queen <a href="Juliana%20of%20the%20Netherlands">Juliana of the Netherlands</a> to Indonesia, on 27 December 1949. On that day, Sukarno flew from Yogyakarta to <a href="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>, making a triumphant speech at the steps of the governor-general's palace, immediately renamed the <a href="Merdeka%20Palace">Merdeka Palace</a> ("Independence Palace").
President of the United States of Indonesia.
At this time, as part of a compromise with the Dutch, Indonesia adopted a new <a href="Federal%20Constitution%20of%201949">federal constitution</a> that made the country a federal state called the Republic of <a href="United%20States%20of%20Indonesia">United States of Indonesia</a> (<a href="Indonesian%20language">Indonesian</a>: "Republik Indonesia Serikat, RIS"), consisting of the Republic of Indonesia whose borders were determined by the "Van Mook Line", along with the six states and nine autonomous territories created by the Dutch. During the first half of 1950, these states gradually dissolved themselves as the Dutch military that previously propped them up was withdrawn. In August 1950, with the last state – the <a href="State%20of%20East%20Indonesia">State of East Indonesia</a> – dissolving itself, Sukarno declared a Unitary Republic of Indonesia based on the newly formulated <a href="Provisional%20Constitution%20of%201950">provisional constitution of 1950</a>.
Liberal democracy period (1950-1959).
Both the Federal Constitution of 1949 and the Provisional Constitution of 1950 were parliamentary in nature, where executive authority laid with the prime minister, and which—on paper—limited presidential power. However, even with his formally reduced role, he commanded a good deal of <a href="moral%20authority">moral authority</a> as <a href="Father%20of%20the%20Nation">Father of the Nation</a>.
Instability.
The first years of parliamentary democracy proved to be very unstable for Indonesia. Cabinets fell in rapid succession due to the sharp differences between the various political parties within the <a href="Dewan%20Perwakilan%20Rakyat">newly appointed parliament ("Dewan Perwakilan Rakjat"/DPR)</a>. There were severe disagreements on future path of Indonesian state, between nationalists who wanted a secular state (led by <a href="Partai%20Nasional%20Indonesia">Partai Nasional Indonesia</a> first established by Sukarno), the Islamists who wanted an Islamic state (led by <a href="Masyumi">Masyumi</a> Party), and the communists who wanted a communist state (led by <a href="Indonesian%20Communist%20Party">PKI</a>, only allowed to operate again in 1951). On the economic front, there was severe dissatisfaction with continuing economic domination by large Dutch corporations and the ethnic-Chinese.
Darul Islam rebels.
The <a href="Darul%20Islam%20%28Indonesia%29">Darul Islam</a> rebels under <a href="Sekarmadji%20Maridjan%20Kartosuwiryo">Kartosuwirjo</a> in West Java refused to acknowledge Sukarno's authority and declared an NII (Negara Islam Indonesia – Islamic State of Indonesia) in August 1949. Rebellions in support of Darul Islam also broke out in <a href="South%20Sulawesi">South Sulawesi</a> in 1951, and in <a href="Aceh">Aceh</a> in 1953. Meanwhile, pro-federalism members of the disbanded <a href="Royal%20Dutch%20East%20Indies%20Army">KNIL</a> launched failed rebellion in <a href="Bandung">Bandung</a> (<a href="Legion%20of%20Ratu%20Adil">APRA rebellion</a> of 1950), in <a href="Makassar%20Uprising">Makassar</a> in 1950, and Ambon (<a href="Republic%20of%20South%20Maluku">Republic of South Maluku</a> revolt of 1950).
Division in the Military.
Additionally, the military was torn by hostilities between officers originating from the colonial-era <a href="Royal%20Dutch%20East%20Indies%20Army">KNIL</a>, who wished for a small and elite professional military, and the overwhelming majority of soldiers who started their careers in the Japanese-formed PETA, who were afraid of being discharged and were more known for nationalist-zeal over professionalism.
On 17 October 1952, the leaders of the former-KNIL faction, Army Chief Colonel <a href="Abdul%20Haris%20Nasution">Abdul Haris Nasution</a> and Armed Forces Chief-of-Staff <a href="Tahi%20Bonar%20Simatupang">Tahi Bonar Simatupang</a> mobilised their troops in a show of force. Protesting against attempts by the DPR to interfere in military business on behalf of the former-PETA faction of the military, Nasution and Simatupang had their troops surround the <a href="Merdeka%20Palace">Merdeka Palace</a> and point their tank turrets at the building. Their demand for Sukarno was that the current DPR be dismissed. For this cause, Nasution and Simatupang also mobilised civilian protesters. Sukarno came out of the palace and convinced both the soldiers and the civilians to go home. Nasution and Simatupang were later dismissed. Nasution, however, would be re-appointed as Army Chief after reconciling with Sukarno in 1955.
1955 Legislative elections.
Result.
The <a href="1955%20Indonesian%20legislative%20election">1955 elections</a> produced a new <a href="Dewan%20Perwakilan%20Rakyat">Parliament</a> and a <a href="Constitutional%20Assembly%20of%20Indonesia">Constitutional Assembly</a>. The election results showed equal support for the antagonistic powers of the PNI, Masyumi, <a href="Nahdlatul%20Ulama">Nahdlatul Ulama</a>, and PKI parties. With no faction controlling a clear majority, domestic political instability continued unabated. Talks in the Constitutional Assembly to write a new constitution met with deadlock over the issue of whether to include Islamic law.
Sukarno came to resent his figurehead position and the increasing disorder of the country's political life. Claiming that Western-style <a href="parliamentary%20democracy">parliamentary democracy</a> was unsuitable for Indonesia, he called for a system of "<a href="guided%20democracy">guided democracy</a>," which he claimed was based on indigenous principles of governance. Sukarno argued that at the village level, important questions were decided by lengthy <a href="deliberation">deliberation</a> designed to achieve a <a href="consensus">consensus</a>, under the guidance of village elders. He believed it should be the model for the entire nation, with the president taking the role assumed by village elders. He proposed a government based not only on <a href="political%20parties">political parties</a> but on "functional groups" composed of the nation's essential elements, which would together form a National Council, through which a national consensus could express itself under presidential guidance.
Vice President <a href="Mohammad%20Hatta">Mohammad Hatta</a> was strongly opposed to Sukarno's guided democracy concept. Citing this and other irreconcilable differences, Hatta resigned from his position in December 1956. His retirement sent a shockwave across Indonesia, particularly among the non-Javanese, who viewed Hatta as their representative in a Javanese-dominated government.
Military takeovers and Martial law.
Regional military takeovers.
From December 1956 to January 1957, regional military commanders in North Sumatra, Central Sumatra, and South Sumatra provinces took over local government control. They declared a series of military councils which were to run their respective areas and refused to accept orders from Jakarta. A similar regional military movement took control of North Sulawesi in March 1957. They demanded the elimination of communist influence in government, equal share in government revenues, and reinstatement of the former Sukarno-<a href="Mohammad%20Hatta">Hatta</a> duumvirate.
Declaration of martial law.
Faced with this serious challenge to the unity of the republic, Sukarno declared <a href="martial%20law">martial law</a> ("Staat van Oorlog en Beleg") on 14 March 1957. He appointed a non-partisan prime minister <a href="Djuanda%20Kartawidjaja">Djuanda Kartawidjaja</a>, while the military was in the hands of his loyal General <a href="Abdul%20Haris%20Nasution">Nasution</a>. Nasution increasingly shared Sukarno's views on the negative impact of western democracy on Indonesia, and he saw a more significant role for the military in political life.
As a reconciliatory move, Sukarno invited the leaders of the regional councils to Jakarta on 10–14 September 1957, to attend a National Conference ("Musjawarah Nasional"), which failed to bring a solution to the crisis. On 30 November 1957, an <a href="assassination">assassination</a> attempt was made on Sukarno by way of a grenade attack while he was visiting a school function in <a href="Menteng">Cikini</a>, <a href="Central%20Jakarta">Central Jakarta</a>. Six children were killed, but Sukarno did not suffer any serious wounds. The perpetrators were members of the <a href="Darul%20Islam%20%28Indonesia%29">Darul Islam</a> group, under the order of its leader <a href="Sekarmadji%20Maridjan%20Kartosuwirjo">Sekarmadji Maridjan Kartosuwirjo</a>.
By December 1957, Sukarno began to take serious steps to enforce his authority over the country. On that month, he nationalised 246 Dutch companies which had been dominating the Indonesian economy, most notably the <a href="Netherlands%20Trading%20Society">NHM</a>, <a href="Royal%20Dutch%20Shell">Royal Dutch Shell</a> subsidiary "Bataafsche Petroleum Maatschappij", Escomptobank, and the "big five" Dutch trading corporations ("NV Borneo Sumatra Maatschappij / Borsumij", "NV Internationale Crediet- en Handelsvereeneging "Rotterdam" / Internatio", "NV Jacobson van den Berg & Co", "NV Lindeteves-Stokvis", and "NV Geo Wehry & Co"), and expelled 40,000 <a href="Indo%20people">Dutch citizens</a> remaining in Indonesia while confiscating their properties, purportedly due to the failure by the Dutch government to continue negotiations on the fate of <a href="Netherlands%20New%20Guinea">Netherlands New Guinea</a> as was promised in the 1949 Round Table Conference. Sukarno's policy of economic nationalism was strengthened by the issuance Presidential Directive No. 10 of 1959, which banned commercial activities by foreign nationals in rural areas. This rule targeted ethnic Chinese, who dominated both the rural and urban retail economy, although at this time few of them had Indonesian citizenship. This policy resulted in massive relocation of the rural ethnic-Chinese population to urban areas, and approximately 100,000 chose to return to China.
To face the dissident regional commanders, Sukarno and Army Chief Nasution decided to take drastic steps following the failure of "Musjawarah Nasional". By utilizing regional officers that remained loyal to Jakarta, Nasution organised a series of "regional coups" which ousted the dissident commanders in North Sumatra (Colonel Maludin Simbolon) and South Sumatra (Colonel Barlian) by December 1957. This returned government control over key cities of <a href="Medan">Medan</a> and <a href="Palembang">Palembang</a>.
In February 1958, the remaining dissident commanders in Central Sumatra (Colonel Ahmad Hussein) and North Sulawesi (Colonel Ventje Sumual) declared the <a href="Revolutionary%20Government%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20Indonesia">PRRI</a>-<a href="Permesta">Permesta</a> Movement aimed at overthrowing the Jakarta government. They were joined by many civilian politicians from the <a href="Masyumi">Masyumi</a> Party, such as <a href="Sjafruddin%20Prawiranegara">Sjafruddin Prawiranegara</a> who were opposed to the growing influence of communists. Due to their anti-communist rhetoric, the rebels received money, weapons, and manpower from the <a href="Central%20Intelligence%20Agency">CIA</a> in a campaign known as Archipelago. This support ended when <a href="Allen%20Lawrence%20Pope">Allen Lawrence Pope</a>, an American pilot, was shot down after a bombing raid on government-held <a href="Ambon%2C%20Maluku">Ambon</a> in April 1958. In April 1958, the central government responded by launching airborne and seaborne military invasions on <a href="Padang%2C%20Indonesia">Padang</a> and <a href="Manado">Manado</a>, the rebel capitals. By the end of 1958, the rebels had been militarily defeated, and the last remaining rebel guerrilla bands surrendered in August 1961.
Guided Democracy period (1959-1966).
The impressive military victories over the PRRI-Permesta rebels and the popular nationalisation of Dutch companies left Sukarno in a firm position. On 5 July 1959, Sukarno reinstated the 1945 constitution by <a href="President%20Sukarno%27s%201959%20Decree">presidential decree</a>. It established a presidential system which he believed would make it easier to implement the principles of guided democracy. He called the system "Manifesto Politik" or Manipol—but it was actually government by decree. Sukarno envisioned an Indonesian-style socialist society, adherent to the principle of USDEK:
In March 1960, Sukarno disbanded parliament and replaced it with a new parliament where half the members were appointed by the president ("Dewan Perwakilan Rakjat – Gotong Rojong" / DPR-GR). In September 1960, he established a <a href="People%27s%20Consultative%20Assembly">Provisional People's Consultative Assembly</a> ("Madjelis Permusjawaratan Rakjat Sementara"/MPRS) as the highest legislative authority according to the 1945 constitution. MPRS members consisted of members of DPR-GR and members of "functional groups" appointed by the president.
With the backing of the military, Sukarno disbanded the Islamic party <a href="Masyumi%20Party">Masyumi</a> and <a href="Sutan%20Sjahrir">Sutan Sjahrir</a>'s party <a href="Socialist%20Party%20of%20Indonesia">PSI</a>, accusing them of involvement with PRRI-Permesta affair. The military arrested and imprisoned many of Sukarno's political opponents, from socialist <a href="Sjahrir">Sjahrir</a> to Islamic politicians <a href="Mohammad%20Natsir">Mohammad Natsir</a> and <a href="Hamka">Hamka</a>. Using martial law powers, the government closed-down newspapers who were critical of Sukarno's policies.
During this period, there were several assassination attempts on Sukarno's life. On 9 March 1960, Daniel Maukar, an Indonesian airforce lieutenant who sympathised with the <a href="Permesta">Permesta</a> rebellion, strafed the <a href="Merdeka%20Palace">Merdeka Palace</a> and <a href="Bogor%20Palace">Bogor Palace</a> with his <a href="MiG-17">MiG-17</a> fighter jet, attempting to kill the president; he was not injured. In May 1962, <a href="Darul%20Islam%20%28Indonesia%29">Darul Islam</a> agents shot at the president during <a href="Eid%20al-Adha">Eid al-Adha</a> prayers on the grounds of the palace. Sukarno again escaped injury.
On the security front, the military started a series of effective campaigns which ended the long-festering Darul Islam rebellion in West Java (1962), Aceh (1962), and South Sulawesi (1965). <a href="Sekarmadji%20Maridjan%20Kartosuwirjo">Kartosuwirjo</a>, the leader of Darul Islam, was captured and executed in September 1962.
To counterbalance the power of the military, Sukarno started to rely on the support of the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Indonesia">Communist Party of Indonesia</a> (PKI). In 1960, he declared his government to be based on <a href="Nasakom">Nasakom</a>, a union of the three ideological strands present in Indonesian society: "nasionalisme" (nationalism), "agama" (religions), and "komunisme" (communism). Accordingly, Sukarno started admitting more communists into his government, while developing a strong relationship with the PKI chairman <a href="Dipa%20Nusantara%20Aidit">Dipa Nusantara Aidit</a>.
In order to increase Indonesia's prestige, Sukarno supported and won the bid for the <a href="1962%20Asian%20Games">1962 Asian Games</a> held in <a href="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>. Many sporting facilities such as the Senayan sports complex (including the 100,000-seat <a href="Bung%20Karno%20Stadium">Bung Karno Stadium</a>) were built to accommodate the games. There was political tension when the Indonesians refused the entry of delegations from <a href="Israel">Israel</a> and <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. After the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> imposed sanctions on Indonesia due to this exclusion policy, Sukarno retaliated by organising a "non-imperialist" competitor event to the <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a>, called the "Games of New Emerging Forces" (<a href="GANEFO">GANEFO</a>). GANEFO was successfully held in Jakarta in November 1963 and was attended by 2,700 athletes from 51 countries.
As part of his prestige-building program, Sukarno ordered the construction of large monumental buildings such as <a href="National%20Monument%20%28Indonesia%29">National Monument ("Monumen Nasional")</a>, <a href="Istiqlal%20Mosque%2C%20Jakarta">Istiqlal Mosque, Jakarta</a>, <a href="CONEFO">CONEFO</a> Building (now the <a href="DPR/MPR%20Building">Parliament Building</a>), <a href="Hotel%20Indonesia">Hotel Indonesia</a>, and the Sarinah shopping centre to transform Jakarta from a former colonial backwater to a modern city. The modern Jakarta boulevards of Jalan Thamrin, Jalan Sudirman, and Jalan Gatot Subroto were planned and constructed under Sukarno.
Foreign policy.
Bandung conference.
On the international front, Sukarno organised the <a href="Bandung%20Conference">Bandung Conference</a> in 1955, with the goal of uniting the developing Asian and African countries into the <a href="Non-Aligned%20Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a> to counter both the United States and the Soviet Union.
Cold War.
As Sukarno's domestic authority was secured, he began to pay more attention to the world stage. He embarked on a series of aggressive and assertive policies based on <a href="anti-imperialism">anti-imperialism</a> to increase Indonesia's international prestige. These anti-imperialist and anti-Western policies, often employing <a href="brinkmanship">brinkmanship</a> with other nations, were also designed to unite the diverse and fractious Indonesian people. In this, he was aided by his Foreign Minister <a href="Subandrio">Subandrio</a>.
After his first visit to <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a> in 1956, Sukarno began to strengthen his ties to the People's Republic of China and the communist bloc in general. He also began to accept increasing amounts of <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet</a>-bloc military aid. By the early 1960s, the Soviet bloc provided more aid to Indonesia than to any other non-communist country, while Soviet military aid to Indonesia was equalled only by its aid to Cuba. This substantial influx of communist aid prompted an increase in military aid from the <a href="Dwight%20D.%20Eisenhower">Dwight Eisenhower</a> and <a href="John%20Fitzgerald%20Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a> Administrations, which worried about a leftward drift should Sukarno rely too much on Soviet-bloc aid.
Sukarno was feted during his visit to the United States in 1956, where he addressed a joint session of the <a href="United%20States%20Congress">United States Congress</a>. To date, it is the only time any Indonesian President has addressed a joint session of the U.S. Congress. Soon after his first visit to America, Sukarno visited the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, where he received a more lavish welcome. Soviet Premier <a href="Nikita%20Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> paid a return visit to <a href="Jakarta">Jakarta</a> and <a href="Bali">Bali</a> in 1960, where he awarded Sukarno with the <a href="Lenin%20Peace%20Prize">Lenin Peace Prize</a>. To make amends for CIA involvement in the PRRI-Permesta rebellion, U.S. President <a href="John%20Fitzgerald%20Kennedy">Kennedy</a> invited Sukarno to Washington, D.C. and provided Indonesia with billions of dollars in civilian and military aid.
To follow up on the successful 1955 <a href="Bandung%20Conference">Bandung Conference</a>, Sukarno attempted to forge a new alliance called the "New Emerging Forces" (NEFO), as a counter to the Western superpowers dubbed the "Old Established Forces" (OLDEFO), whom he accused of spreading "Neo-Colonialism and Imperialism" (NEKOLIM). In 1961, Sukarno established another political alliance, called the <a href="Non-Aligned%20Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a> (NAM, in Indonesia known as Gerakan Non-Blok, GNB) with Egypt's President <a href="Gamal%20Abdel%20Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a>, India's Prime Minister <a href="Pandit%20Jawaharlal%20Nehru">Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru</a>, <a href="Socialist%20Federal%20Republic%20of%20Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>'s President <a href="Josip%20Broz%20Tito">Josip Broz Tito</a>, and Ghana's President <a href="Kwame%20Nkrumah">Kwame Nkrumah</a>, in an action called The Initiative of Five (Sukarno, Nkrumah, Nasser, Tito, and Nehru). NAM was intended to provide political unity and influence for nations who wished to maintain independence from the American and Soviet superpower blocs, which were engaged in <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a> competition. Sukarno is still fondly remembered for his role in promoting the influence of newly independent countries. His name is used as a street name in <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a>, Egypt and <a href="Rabat">Rabat</a>, Morocco, and as a major square in <a href="Peshawar">Peshawar</a>, Pakistan. In 1956, the <a href="University%20of%20Belgrade">University of Belgrade</a> awarded him an <a href="honorary%20degree">honorary doctorate</a>.
Papua conflict.
In 1960 Sukarno began an aggressive foreign policy to secure Indonesian territorial claims. In August of that year, Sukarno broke off diplomatic relations with the Netherlands over the continuing failure to commence talks on the future of <a href="Netherlands%20New%20Guinea">Netherlands New Guinea</a>, as was agreed at the <a href="Dutch-Indonesian%20Round%20Table%20Conference">Dutch-Indonesian Round Table Conference</a> of 1949. In April 1961, the Dutch announced the formation of a "<a href="Nieuw%20Guinea%20Raad">Nieuw Guinea Raad</a>", intending to create an independent <a href="Papua%20New%20Guinea">Papuan</a> state. Sukarno declared a state of military confrontation in his "<a href="Operation%20Trikora">Tri Komando Rakjat</a>" (TRIKORA) speech in <a href="Yogyakarta">Yogyakarta</a>, on 19 December 1961. He then directed military incursions into the half-island, which he referred to as <a href="West%20Irian">West Irian</a>. By the end of 1962, 3,000 Indonesian soldiers were present throughout West Irian/West Papua.
A naval battle erupted in January 1962 when four Indonesian <a href="torpedo%20boat">torpedo boat</a>s were intercepted by Dutch ships and planes off the coast of Vlakke Hoek. One Indonesian boat was sunk, killing the Naval Deputy Chief-of-Staff <a href="Commodore%20%28rank%29">Commodore</a> <a href="Yos%20Sudarso">Jos Sudarso</a>. Meanwhile, the Kennedy Administration worried of a continuing Indonesian shift towards communism should the Dutch hold on to West Irian/West Papua. In February 1962 <a href="Attorney%20General%20of%20the%20United%20States">U.S. Attorney General</a> <a href="Robert%20F.%20Kennedy">Robert F. Kennedy</a> travelled to the Netherlands and informed the government that the United States would not support the Netherlands in an armed conflict with Indonesia. With Soviet armaments and advisors, Sukarno planned a large-scale air- and seaborne invasion of the Dutch military headquarters of <a href="Biak">Biak</a> for August 1962, called "Operasi Djajawidjaja". It was to be led by Major-General <a href="Suharto">Suharto</a>, the future President of Indonesia. Before these plans could be realised, Indonesia and the Netherlands signed the <a href="New%20York%20Agreement">New York Agreement</a> in August 1962. The two countries agreed to implement the Bunker Plan (formulated by American diplomat <a href="Ellsworth%20Bunker">Ellsworth Bunker</a>), whereby the Dutch agreed to hand over West Irian/West Papua to <a href="United%20Nations%20Temporary%20Executive%20Authority">UNTEA</a> on 1 October 1962. UNTEA transferred the territory to Indonesian authority in May 1963.
"Konfrontasi".
After securing control over West Irian/West Papua, Sukarno then opposed the British-supported establishment of the <a href="Malaysia">Federation of Malaysia</a> in 1963, claiming that it was a neo-colonial plot by the British to undermine Indonesia. Despite Sukarno's political overtures, which found some support when leftist political elements in British Borneo territories <a href="Sarawak">Sarawak</a> and <a href="Brunei">Brunei</a> opposed the Federation plan and aligned themselves with Sukarno, Malaysia was established in September 1963. This was followed by the <a href="Indonesia%E2%80%93Malaysia%20confrontation">Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation</a> ("Konfrontasi"), proclaimed by Sukarno in his "Dwi Komando Rakjat" (DWIKORA) speech in Jakarta on 3 May 1964. Sukarno's proclaimed objective was not, as some alleged, to annex <a href="Sabah">Sabah</a> and <a href="Sarawak">Sarawak</a> into Indonesia, but to establish a "State of North Kalimantan" under the control of <a href="North%20Kalimantan%20Communist%20Party">North Kalimantan Communist Party</a>. From 1964 until early 1966, a limited number of Indonesian soldiers, civilians, and Malaysian communist guerrillas were sent into North Borneo and the Malay Peninsula. These forces fought against British and Commonwealth soldiers deployed to protect the nascent state of Malaysia. Indonesian agents also exploded several bombs in <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a>. Domestically, Sukarno fomented anti-British sentiment, and the British Embassy was burned down. In 1964, all British companies operating in the country, including Indonesian operations of the <a href="Chartered%20Bank">Chartered Bank</a> and <a href="Unilever">Unilever</a>, were nationalised. The confrontation came to a climax during August 1964, when Sukarno authorised landings of Indonesian troops at <a href="Landing%20at%20Pontian">Pontian</a> and <a href="Landing%20at%20Labis">Labis</a> on the Malaysian mainland, and all-out war seemed inevitable as tensions escalated. However, the situation calmed by mid-September at the culmination of the <a href="Sunda%20Straits%20Crisis">Sunda Straits Crisis</a>, and after the disastrous <a href="Battle%20of%20Plaman%20Mapu">Battle of Plaman Mapu</a> in April 1965, Indonesian raids into Sarawak became fewer and weaker.
In 1964, Sukarno commenced an anti-American campaign, which was motivated by his shift towards the communist bloc and less friendly relations with the <a href="Presidency%20of%20Lyndon%20B.%20Johnson">Lyndon Johnson administration</a>. American interests and businesses in Indonesia were denounced by government officials and attacked by <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Indonesia">PKI</a>-led mobs. American movies were banned, American books and <a href="Beatles">Beatles</a> albums were burned, and the Indonesian band <a href="Koes%20Plus">Koes Plus</a> was jailed for playing American-style <a href="rock%20and%20roll">rock and roll</a> music. As a result, U.S. aid to Indonesia was halted, to which Sukarno made his famous remark, "Go to hell with your aid". Sukarno withdrew Indonesia from the <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a> on 7 January 1965 when, with U.S. backing, Malaysia took a seat on <a href="UN%20Security%20Council">UN Security Council</a>.
Conference of New Emerging Forces.
As the NAM countries were becoming split into different factions, and as fewer countries were willing to support his anti-Western foreign policies, Sukarno began to abandon his non-alignment rhetoric. Sukarno formed a new alliance with <a href="China">China</a>, <a href="North%20Korea">North Korea</a>, <a href="North%20Vietnam">North Vietnam</a>, and Cambodia which he called the "<a href="Beijing">Beijing</a>-<a href="Pyongyang">Pyongyang</a>-<a href="Hanoi">Hanoi</a>-<a href="Phnom%20Penh">Phnom Penh</a>-<a href="Jakarta">Jakarta</a> Axis". After withdrawing Indonesia from the "imperialist-dominated" <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a> in January 1965, Sukarno sought to establish a competitor organisation to the UN called the Conference of New Emerging Forces (<a href="CONEFO">CONEFO</a>) with support from the People's Republic of China, which at that time was <a href="China%20and%20the%20United%20Nations">not yet a member of United Nations</a>. With the government heavily indebted to the Soviet Union, Indonesia became increasingly dependent on China for support. Sukarno spoke increasingly of a Beijing-Jakarta axis, which would be the core of a new anti-imperialist world organisation, the CONEFO.
Domestic policy.
President for life and Cult of personality.
Domestically, Sukarno continued to consolidate his control. He was made <a href="president%20for%20life">president for life</a> by the <a href="People%27s%20Consultative%20Assembly">MPRS</a> in 1963. His ideological writings on Manipol-USDEK and NASAKOM became mandatory subjects in Indonesian schools and universities, while his speeches were to be memorised and discussed by all students. All newspapers, the only radio station (<a href="Radio%20Republik%20Indonesia">RRI</a>, government-run), and the only television station (<a href="TVRI">TVRI</a>, also government-run) were made into "tools of the revolution" and functioned to spread Sukarno's messages. Sukarno developed a <a href="personality%20cult">personality cult</a>, with the capital of newly acquired <a href="Western%20New%20Guinea">West Irian</a> renamed to <a href="Jayapura">Sukarnapura</a> and the highest peak in the country was renamed from Carstensz Pyramid to <a href="Puncak%20Jaya">Puntjak Sukarno (Sukarno Peak)</a>.
Rise of the PKI.
Despite these appearances of unchallenged control, Sukarno's guided democracy stood on fragile grounds due to the inherent conflict between its two underlying support pillars, the military and the communists. The military, nationalists, and the Islamic groups were shocked by the rapid growth of the communist party under Sukarno's protection. They feared an imminent establishment of a communist state in Indonesia. By 1965, the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Indonesia">PKI</a> had three million members and were particularly strong in <a href="Central%20Java">Central Java</a> and <a href="Bali">Bali</a>. PKI had become the strongest party in Indonesia.
The military and nationalists were growing wary of Sukarno's close alliance with communist China, which they thought compromised Indonesia's sovereignty. Elements of the military disagreed with Sukarno's policy of confrontation with Malaysia, which in their view only benefited communists, and sent several officers (including future Armed Forces Chief <a href="Leonardus%20Benjamin%20Moerdani">Leonardus Benjamin Moerdani</a>) to spread secret peace-feelers to the Malaysian government. The Islamic clerics, who were mostly landowners, felt threatened by PKI's land confiscation actions ("aksi sepihak") in the countryside and by the communist campaign against the "seven village devils", a term used for landlords or better-off farmers (similar to the anti-<a href="kulak">kulak</a> campaign in <a href="Stalinism">Stalinist</a> era). Both groups harboured deep disdain for PKI in particular due to memories of the bloody <a href="Madiun%20Affair">1948 communist rebellion</a>.
As the mediator of the three groups under the NASAKOM system, Sukarno displayed greater sympathies to the communists. The PKI had been very careful to support all of Sukarno's policies. Meanwhile, Sukarno saw the PKI as the best-organised and ideologically solid party in Indonesia, and a useful conduit to gain more military and financial aid from <a href="Eastern%20Bloc">Communist Bloc</a> countries. Sukarno also sympathised with the communists' revolutionary ideals, which were similar to his own.
To weaken the influence of the military, Sukarno rescinded martial law (which gave wide-ranging powers to the military) in 1963. In September 1962, he "promoted" the powerful General Nasution to the less-influential position of Armed Forces Chief, while the influential position of Army Chief was given to Sukarno's loyalist <a href="Ahmad%20Yani">Ahmad Yani</a>. Meanwhile, the position of Air Force Chief was given to <a href="Omar%20Dhani">Omar Dhani</a>, who was an open communist sympathiser. In May 1964, Sukarno banned activities of "Manifesto Kebudajaan" (Manikebu), an association of artists and writers which included prominent Indonesian writers such as Hans Bague Jassin and Wiratmo Soekito, who were also dismissed from their jobs. Manikebu was considered a rival by the communist writer's association "<a href="Lembaga%20Kebudajaan%20Rakjat">Lembaga Kebudajaan Rakjat</a>" (Lekra), led by <a href="Pramoedya%20Ananta%20Toer">Pramoedya Ananta Toer</a>. In December 1964, Sukarno disbanded the "Badan Pendukung Soekarnoisme" (BPS), the "Association for Promoting Sukarnoism", an organisation that seeks to oppose communism by invoking Sukarno's own <a href="Pancasila%20%28politics%29">Pancasila</a> formulation. In January 1965, Sukarno, under pressure from PKI, banned the <a href="Murba%20Party">Murba Party</a>. Murba was a <a href="Trotskyism">Trotskyite</a> party whose ideology was antagonistic to PKI's orthodox line of Marxism.
Tensions between the military and communists increased in April 1965, when PKI chairman <a href="Aidit">Aidit</a> called for the formation of a "fifth armed force" consisting of armed peasants and labour. Sukarno approved this idea and publicly called for the immediate formation of such a force on 17 May 1965.
